channel.title: About Us on InLab - Inference Laboratory
channel.description: Recent content in About Us on InLab - Inference Laboratory

item.title: CoFI workshop at ASEG Discover 2024
item.description: Preparations are well underway for InLab’s workshop at ASEG Discover 2024. Attendees will be provided with a hands-on experience of InLab’s emerging geoscience inference softwared ecosystem centred around CoFI, InLab’s common framework for inference. The following link allows to register for ASEG Discover 2024 and our workshop asegdiscover.com.au/registration

item.title: EGU 2024 CoFI Poster
item.description: InLab researchers have recently presented several new research results at the European Geosciences Union meeting in Vienna, 15 Apr. There were talks on BayesBay, our new Trans-dimensional inference platform available through CoFI, and also a progress report on development of an ‘Independent state’ sampler, which will become part of CoFI in the future. We also presented an updated CoFI poster (see below) and discussed with European researchers how they might become engaged with the CoFI community.

item.title: Espresso presentation at EGU 2023 by Andrew Valentine
item.description: If you have an inverse problem you would like to share or are looking for a test case for your inference algorithm then Espresso might be for you. The slides from Andrew Valentine’s presentation at EGU2023 are available here.

item.title: Sub22 CoFI Workshop
item.description: InLab held its first hands-on public workshop centred around CoFI at the National Wine Centre in Adelaide with attendees from industry, government and academia. The workshop complemented sub22, the CSIRO’s Deep Earth Imaging Future Science Platform organised biennial subsurface imaging conference.

item.title: CoFI
item.description: The development of CoFI is now being supported through an AuScope 2021 Pilot Project.

item.title: Tearing down barriers...
item.description: Using polynomial regression as an example we explore how CoFI allows us to swap between fundamentally different inference and optimisation approaches without the need to redefine the problem.

item.title: 2020 Gutenberg Lecture
item.description: The American Geophysical Union has awarded the 2020 Gutenberg Lecture to Prof. Malcolm Sambridge.
